excerpt: Dating back to 3rd century BCE, this large necropolis features underground tombs carved out of rock.
detail_description: The Archaeological Site of the Tombs of the Kings is a vast necropolis dating back to the 3rd century BCE. It boasts underground tombs that were meticulously carved out of rock. The site offers a glimpse into ancient burial practices and architectural ingenuity. Additionally, visitors can explore nearby attractions such as the Medieval Castle, waterfront restaurants, ice-cream shops, cafes, and bars with stunning views across the water and harbor.
name: Archaeological Site of the Tombs of the Kings
address: Tombs of the Kings Ave 63, Chlorakas 8015, Cyprus

excerpt: First a Byzantine fort, this castle was rebuilt throughout the years & used as a prison & warehouse.
detail_description: Paphos Castle, originally a Byzantine fort, has a rich history of destruction and reconstruction. Over the years, it has served as a prison and warehouse for salt. The castle stands at the edge of Paphos harbor and is one of the city's most recognizable landmarks. It hosts various events throughout the year, including operas during the Paphos Aphrodite Festival.
name: Paphos Castle
address: Kato Paphos Harbour, Coastal Broadwalk, Paphos 8040, Cyprus

excerpt: Archaeological park featuring the remains of a Greek-Roman city, including villas, mosaics & more.
detail_description: Kato Pafos Archaeological Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1980, is a sprawling complex that encompasses remnants from various historical periods. This includes prehistoric sites, medieval structures, and Roman-era monuments. The park is renowned for its well-preserved mosaic floors depicting scenes from Greek mythology, found in several Roman villas within the site.
name: Kato Pafos Archaeological Park

excerpt: Paphos is a city on the southwest coast of the Mediterranean island of Cyprus. Inhabited since Neolithic times, it has several sites relating to the cult of goddess Aphrodite, whose mythical birthplace was at Old Paphos (Kouklia). New Paphos is the modern city that incorporates the harbor, and the ancient ruins of tombs, fortresses, theaters and villas at Paphos Archaeological Park.
detail_description: Paphos, located on the southwest coast of Cyprus, is a city with a rich history dating back to Neolithic times. It is associated with the cult of goddess Aphrodite and boasts ancient ruins such as tombs, fortresses, theaters, and villas at Paphos Archaeological Park. The modern city incorporates the harbor and offers a blend of Greek mythology, churches, castles, and monasteries against the backdrop of the azure sea.
name: Paphos

detail_description: The Old Town of Paphos, also known as Ktima, is a charming area that showcases the rich history of this town. It features a mix of medieval, Ottoman, and neoclassical architecture, offering visitors a glimpse into the island's colonial past. This part of Paphos is renowned for its beauty and historical significance, making it a must-visit for travelers interested in exploring ancient times.
name: Old Town of Paphos

excerpt: Big archaeological area featuring ruins such as tombs, villas & a fortress, plus Roman mosaics.
detail_description: The Archaeological Site of Nea Paphos is a sprawling area filled with ancient ruins, including tombs, villas, and a fortress. The site also boasts well-preserved Roman mosaics depicting ancient mythology. Visitors can explore the Medieval Castle and enjoy stunning views of the water and harbor. The area is bustling with waterfront restaurants, shops, and yachts, creating a vibrant atmosphere that blends seamlessly with its rich historical significance.
name: Archaeological Site of Nea Paphos

excerpt: Museum housing archaeological artifacts from the Neolithic period to the Middle Ages.
detail_description: The Archaeological Museum of the Paphos District is home to a diverse collection of archaeological artifacts spanning from the Neolithic period to the Middle Ages. The museum showcases items excavated from various sites in the Paphos district, offering insights into human activity in western Cyprus over centuries. Visitors can explore relics such as ceramic vessels, ancient pottery, jewelry, coins, stone sarcophagi, and Roman marble sculptures across five exhibition rooms and a yard.
name: Archaeological Museum of the Paphos District

excerpt: Preserved ruins of a Roman villa dating to the 2nd, century known for colorful mosaics of Dionysus.
detail_description: The House of Dionysus is a well-preserved Roman villa in Paphos, dating back to the 2nd century. It is renowned for its vibrant and detailed mosaic pavements depicting scenes from Greek mythology. These mosaics are considered among the finest in the Mediterranean and are part of the larger Paphos Archaeological Site. Discovered by chance, the artwork showcases narratives of love and celebration with meticulous patterns and natural limestone colors.
name: House of Dionysus

excerpt: Ancient Roman structures containing preserved mosaics depicting mythological scenes.
detail_description: Paphos Mosaics are ancient Roman structures in Cyprus, showcasing well-preserved mosaics depicting mythological scenes. The mosaics date back to the Hellenistic period and are considered among the finest in the world. The site includes mosaics from various periods, including the Hellenistic and Byzantine eras. Additionally, Paphos Castle, a Byzantine fort, offers a glimpse into history and hosts events like the Paphos Aphrodite Festival.
name: Paphos Mosaics

excerpt: A lively resort area near Paphos Harbour, Kato Paphos is dotted with hotels, souvenir shops, and tavernas serving fish and meze meals. Ayiou Antoniou street is home to bars, live music venues, and nightclubs. Lined with sunbeds, Alykes Beach is popular for watersports. Inland are the 1500s Agia Kyriaki church, set among the ruins of the early-Christian Chrysopolitissa Basilica, and the centuries-old Ottoman Baths.
detail_description: Kato Paphos, a vibrant resort area near Paphos Harbour, is known for its abundance of hotels, souvenir shops, and tavernas offering delectable fish and meze dishes. Ayiou Antoniou street boasts a lively nightlife scene with bars, live music venues, and nightclubs. Alykes Beach attracts visitors with its sunbed-lined shores and popular watersports activities.
name: Kato Paphos

excerpt: Ruins of a charming, rustic church, built in the 13th century & known for its colorful mosaic floor.
detail_description: Agia Kyriaki Chrysopolitissa is a historical site in Paphos, Cyprus, featuring the ruins of a 13th-century church known for its colorful mosaic floor. The site was once home to one of Pafos' largest religious structures, with the remaining foundations showcasing the size and grandeur of the original church.
name: Agia Kyriaki Chrysopolitissa

excerpt: Family-friendly water park featuring slides, a lazy river, a wave pool, a kids' area & concessions.
detail_description: Paphos Aphrodite Waterpark is the largest water park in the Paphos area, offering a unique natural landscape for aquatic adventures. Located in Kato Paphos, it is easily accessible by car or local bus. The park features high-speed water slides, a lazy river, wave surge pool, swimming areas, and a kids' water-play section. Visitors can also enjoy food and beverage options spread throughout the park within lush tropical surroundings.
name: Paphos Aphrodite Waterpark

detail_description: Paphos Town Market is a bustling indoor market featuring an array of small shops offering a variety of goods such as tourist souvenirs, clothing, beachwear, and faux leather items. Visitors can leisurely explore the market and discover stalls selling traditional Lefkara lace, tablecloths, ceramics, soaps, and locally produced wine. The market provides a unique shopping experience with its distinct Cypriot products.
name: Old Town Market

excerpt: Sheltered inlet with sandy shores & calm waters, plus water sports, lodging & cocktail bars.
detail_description: The beach Alykes is a lovely and peaceful spot, with calm waters and sandy shores. It's perfect for swimming, sunbathing, and enjoying water sports. There are also some good places to eat and drink in the area, and it's a great place to relax on an autumn day.
name: Alykes Beach

detail_description: The Place is a hidden gem in Paphos, offering a unique shopping and cultural experience for the whole family. With over 12 workshops featuring local artists, visitors can explore authentic handcrafted items and learn about local customs and traditions. The venue also provides accommodation with stunning views, making it an ideal destination for travelers. Whether you're interested in budget-friendly shopping or immersing yourself in the local arts and crafts scene, The Place has something to offer for everyone visiting Paphos.
name: The Place

excerpt: Remains of a 2nd-century Roman house with a preserved mosaic showing Theseus fighting the Minotaur.
detail_description: This imposing Roman villa was the residence of a proconsul or governor, and is now divided between rooms for official functions and those for private use. The mosaic of Theseus and the Minotaur found in its southeast quarter is truly beautiful, illustrating how much labour went into its preparation.
name: Villa of Theseus

excerpt: Compact shrine & series of stone tomb chambers with remnants of 12th-century religious paintings.
detail_description: Agia Solomoni Catacomb, also known as the Catacombs of Saint Solomonia or Hagia Solomonia, is a significant site for Christian believers in Cyprus and a popular tourist destination. This large cave Christian temple was initially used as catacombs for stone extraction before being repurposed as a burial site and later transformed into a Christian Orthodox Church in the 9th century.
name: Agia Solomoni Catacomb

detail_description: St. Paul's Church and archaeological site in Paphos, Cyprus, holds great historical and religious significance. According to tradition, the ancient white marble pillar on the site is where the apostle Paul was flogged during his visit to Cyprus in 1st century AD. The area also features the ruins of the Panagia Chrysopolitissa Basilica and a modern Greek Orthodox church called Agia Kyriaki Chrysopolitissa with beautiful mosaics often used for weddings.
name: Saint Paul's Pillar

detail_description: House of Aion is an ancient Roman villa with a mosaic floor that is considered one of the most exceptional works of ancient Roman art. The villa was probably used as a reception room and contains wall paintings in the Archaeological Museum in Warsaw.
name: House of Aion

excerpt: Chloraka is a village in the Paphos District of Cyprus, 3 km north of Paphos. The town is host to Akritas Chlorakas, a Cypriot First Division football team. Wikipedia.
detail_description: Chloraka, a charming village located just 3 km north of Paphos in Cyprus, offers a blend of history, nature, and community. The town is home to the successful Cypriot First Division football team Akritas Chlorakas. Visitors can explore parks, museums, and ancient churches nestled amidst lush greenery. Additionally, the area boasts kindergartens and is conveniently close to the British private school Aspire.
name: Chlorakas

detail_description: Paphos Lighthouse, also known as Paphos Faros, is a historic structure in Cyprus that was built in 1888 during British colonial rule. Standing at 20 meters tall, it served as a crucial marker for ships traveling through the Suez Canal to the colonies and guided vessels to Paphos harbor from Britain. Situated amidst Roman ruins, the lighthouse offers stunning views of the bay and features nearby exhibitions on seafaring and lighthouses.
name: Paphos Lighthouse

detail_description: Lighthouse Beach in Paphos is a serene and easily accessible spot, offering a relaxing atmosphere away from the city. To reach the beach bar, visitors can park at the nearby Baths of Aphrodite public parking lot and make their way down to the sand. The area also features a fish restaurant overlooking the beach. Despite ongoing reconstruction, the cafe still serves excellent coffee and fresh orange juice with a breathtaking view of the sea.
name: Lighthouse Beach

detail_description: Municipal Beach in Paphos is a stunning sandy beach offering ideal weather and refreshing breezes for a relaxing day by the sea. Visitors can take a dip in the water or enjoy various watersports activities. The beach provides breathtaking views, making it a must-visit destination for holidaymakers. It is conveniently located near the city and offers sunbeds and umbrellas at standard prices. While not entirely sandy, it is suitable for families with kids.
name: Municipal Beach

detail_description: If you're looking for a delightful getaway in the Paphos harbour area, consider the charming holiday flats and rooms available for rent starting from just 30 euros. With a welcoming reception open around the clock, you can easily find accommodations that suit both short and long-term stays. This vibrant district is not only home to stunning views of golden sands but also boasts an array of restaurants, shops, and bars along its picturesque promenade.
name: Othon holidays flats and rooms

detail_description: The Hellenistic-Roman Theatre is a partially unexcavated archaeological site with a rich history waiting to be explored. Although it is fenced off for protection, visitors can still access a platform from the side of the theater to enjoy impressive views. Despite some litter around the area, it offers a great historical and cultural experience. The site provides excellent photo opportunities and boasts cool locations, fun walks around the bridge, and exploration of nearby caves.
name: Hellenistic-Roman Theatre

detail_description: The Ethnographic Museum, formerly known as the Museum of Folk Art, is a private museum housed in a charming 1894 stone building with gothic arches and beautiful gardens. The collection features artifacts from George Eliadi's personal anthology, including natural caves, a terebinth tree, decorative wooden furniture, Hellenistic period rock carvings, kitchen items, and agricultural tools.
name: Ethnographic Museum

excerpt: Contemporary indoor shopping center with 120+ stores, a food court & a movie theater.
detail_description: Kings Avenue Mall in Paphos, Cyprus is a modern indoor shopping center that opened in 2013 with the aim of becoming the ultimate shopping and entertainment destination for both locals and tourists. With over 120 stores, including high street and designer brands, it offers a wide range of shopping options. The mall also features a food court and a movie theater, providing visitors with dining and entertainment choices.
name: Kings Avenue Mall
address: Corner St. Paul &, Tombs of the Kings Ave 2, Paphos 8046, Cyprus

excerpt: Seaside Byzantine church, founded in the 10th c. CE & rebuilt in 1923, housing treasured icons.
detail_description: Nestled on a small rock near the picturesque Kato Paphos harbor, the Church of Panagia Theoskepasti is a stunning example of Byzantine architecture with roots tracing back to the 10th century. Originally built during Cyprus's time under the Byzantine Empire, this sacred site was reconstructed in 1923 and stands as both a historical landmark and an active spiritual hub.
name: Church of Panagia Theoskepasti

excerpt: Fragmented remains of a Byzantine-era castle, noted for its many granite columns & stone archways.
detail_description: Forty Columns Fortress, also known as Saranta Kolonon Castle, is a significant historical site located on the edge of Paphos harbor. Originally built during the Byzantine period to protect the harbor, it was destroyed in an earthquake and later rebuilt by Lusignan rulers in the 13th century. The Venetians dismantled it during the Ottoman invasion in 1570.
name: Forty Columns Fortress

excerpt: Archeological ruins from prehistoric times to the Middle Ages, including Roman villas with mosaics.
detail_description: The Roman Odeon, located in various archaeological sites across different regions, is a well-preserved ancient theater that dates back to the Roman period. Built around 100 A.D., it was used for theatrical performances and political gatherings. Despite its age, the Odeon has been remarkably preserved with its seating tiers still intact, offering visitors a vivid glimpse into life in Ancient Rome. The site also hosts open-air musical and theatrical performances during the summer months.
name: Roman Odeon

detail_description: The House of Orpheus, a villa named after the mosaic of Orpheus, is a historical site dating back to the 2nd and 3rd centuries. The villa features remarkable mosaics depicting Orpheus surrounded by listening beasts as he plays his lyre. Visitors can enjoy an up-close experience with authentic antiquities and explore the well-preserved Roman architecture at Kato Paphos site.
name: House of Orpheus

detail_description: SODAP Beach, also known as Vrysoudia A, is a spacious and well-maintained beach located in the central area of Paphos. With its 300-meter stretch of fine gray sand mixed with gravel and boulders, it offers a picturesque setting for beach enthusiasts. Visitors can enjoy the convenience of various amenities such as sunbed rentals, a beach bar, showers, toilets, and changing rooms at standard prices.
name: SODAP Beach

detail_description: Island Cove Adventure Mini Golf is a charming and well-maintained 18-hole mini golf course located in the Paphos area. The friendly owner ensures that visitors can enjoy the course without feeling rushed, and there are amenities such as ice cream, toilets, and a car park available. Visitors can even purchase a certificate if they achieve a hole-in-one. The course is reasonably priced and offers an enjoyable experience for both adults and children.
name: Island Cove Adventure Mini Golf

detail_description: 7 St. Georgeâ€™s Tavern is a family-owned meze bar in the charismatic Old Town, offering a unique dining experience with traditional Cypriot dishes. The tavern doesn't have a menu; instead, the host brings around twenty dishes over about two hours, including kleftiko, moussaka, and pork ribs. The meze only costs 22 each and caters to dietary restrictions.
name: 7 St. Georgeâ€™s Tavern

detail_description: Muse is a trendy restaurant and cafe located on a hillside in Paphos, offering breathtaking views of the city and coastline. It's known for its delicious food, especially the burgers, and exceptional cocktails. The modern design of the building with a sail-shaped bar adds to the amazing atmosphere that attracts both locals and tourists. Whether you're looking for fabulous food, great drinks, or stunning views, Muse has it all.
name: Muse

detail_description: The Coastal Boardwalk in Paphos is a newly extended seafront path that spans about five kilometers along the central coastline. The southern section runs from Paphos Fort to the Louis Phaethon Beach Resort, offering a level and enjoyable walk with picturesque views. Although some parts are still under development, it's a favorite spot for walking and running, providing a relaxing and inspiring experience.
name: Coastal Boardwalk

excerpt: Built in 1888, this 20-m. high, whitewashed stone lighthouse can be seen for 17 nautical miles.
detail_description: Paphos Lighthouse, a striking 20-meter tall structure constructed in 1888, is a prominent landmark that offers visibility for up to 17 nautical miles. Visitors can access the lighthouse as part of an entry fee that also includes other nearby attractions such as the Odeon, the house of Dionysus, and Theseus villa. The entrance gate to the park is conveniently located near the harbor's parking area.
name: Paphos Lighthouse

excerpt: Small, scenic beach featuring rental chairs & umbrellas, swimming, sunbathing & harbor/castle views.
detail_description: Vrisoudia II Beach is a small and picturesque beach located just 700 meters from the center of Paphos City. It offers rental chairs and umbrellas, making it perfect for swimming and sunbathing while enjoying views of the harbor and castle. The sandy beach is only 3 meters from the sea, with some occasional seaweed due to windy weather. However, there are lifeguards and umbrella rental services available to maintain the beach's cleanliness.
name: Vrisoudia Î™Î™ Beach

detail_description: The Harbour in Paphos offers a delightful walking route along the scenic marina and port, perfect for a leisurely 30-35 minute stroll or a shorter walk with breaks at the harbor. Sunset walks are particularly recommended for breathtaking views. The restaurant at The Harbour is known for its culinary delights, including salmon with saffron sauce and options for vegetarians and vegans.
name: The Harbour

detail_description: The Agora, located in the southern section of an archaeological site, is home to a stunning collection of mosaics that once adorned the floor space of a grand Roman villa. Discovered in 1962 by a farmer plowing his field, these beautiful mosaics are just one part of the complex which also includes monuments like Asklepieion, Odeon, Saranta Kolones Castle, Limeniotissa ruins and Tombs of the Kings.
name: Agora
address: Frankish Baths, Ayiou Ayapitikou, Paphos 8040, Cyprus

detail_description: Zorbas Bakery is a popular bakery chain in Cyprus that offers a variety of options, including vegan choices marked as Fasting. The bakery is known for its fresh bread, cakes, pastries, salads, and an array of hot and cold food items. With 24/7 opening hours at some locations, it's a convenient spot to grab a meal or snack any time of day. Customers praise the cleanliness of the premises and the friendly staff.
name: Zorbas Bakery (Î¦Î¿ÏÏÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Î–ÎŸÎ¡Î Î‘Î£)

detail_description: The Lighthouse Beach Snack Bar is a lovely place to stop off for a drink or some delicious food on the beautiful Faros beach in Paphos. Right by the coastal path, its an ideal spot to relax and enjoy the views while you take in some great music. The snack bar offers excellent service and great prices so you can indulge in all your favourite foods without breaking the bank. We found it really enjoyable and would definitely recommend a visit!
name: Lighthouse Beach Snack Bar

detail_description: To Kalamaki Tis Polis Pitta Delivery & Takeaway is located in a charming village called Kathikas, which was historically a stop-over for merchants and travelers. The village is known for its vineyards and grape cultivation. The restaurant itself offers a reasonably priced menu with various options to cater to different tastes. It's also praised for serving the best gyros in Cyprus.
name: To Kalamaki Tis Polis Pitta Delivery & Takeaway

detail_description: Tombs of the Kings Ave, also known as Tafoi ton Vasileon, is a UNESCO World Heritage site located near Paphos. Despite its name, it was not the burial place of kings but rather local nobles and high-ranking officials from the 4th century BC to AD300. The tombs are carved into the rock with impressive subterranean chambers featuring frescoed walls and Doric columns.
name: Tombs of the Kings Ave

detail_description: The Ecclesiastical Museum of Pafos, also known as the Byzantine Museum, is a treasure trove for history enthusiasts and art lovers alike. Established in 1914, this charming museum boasts over 25,000 rare artifacts that span from the third century to the late Middle Ages. Nestled within the Bishopric precincts of Paphos, it showcases an impressive collection of ecclesiastical metalwork including candlesticks and chalices from the sixth century.
name: Ecclesiastical Museum of Pafos, Byzantine Museum

detail_description: Moutallos, also referred to as the Old Turkish Quarter, offers a unique opportunity to immerse yourself in the local culture of Paphos while being conveniently located near the city's main attractions. This residential neighborhood is home to many local families, providing visitors with an authentic experience that differs from the more touristy areas like Kato Paphos. If you're looking for a place that offers a glimpse into everyday life in Paphos, Moutallos is an ideal choice.
name: Moutallos

detail_description: Agoras Shop is located in Paphos and is part of a historical site that includes the Odeon theater, Agora marketplace, and remnants of ancient city walls. The market offers a wide variety of mementos, souvenirs, antiques, food, sweets, and handmade lace. Visitors can find good bargains but may need to haggle for lower prices at some stalls.
name: Agoras Shop

detail_description: Cosmic World kidâ€™s entertainment is a fantastic place for families, teenagers, and friends to have a great time. The venue specializes in elaborate bowling alleys that automatically adjust settings for young children. There's also a tablet-equipped waiting area and arcade games for added fun. The complex offers quick service on drinks, good quality lanes, and a variety of arcade games. Families can enjoy the kids' soft play area as well.
name: Cosmic World kidâ€™s entertainment

detail_description: Playground is a small but well-equipped play area with four swings, two carousels, and a slide for young children. The playground features concrete benches for parents to relax while their kids play on the rubber ground. Although it lacks musical equipment and trampolines, it's recommended for a short visit. Additionally, there is another similar playground nearby that offers a more secluded environment.
name: Playground
